scripts.intro:
Hello {name}. I am your Transformation Assistant.

In this Quick Assessment (Free), we will go through 3 steps:
1. Company & expectations
2. Challenges & profile questions
3. Recommendations & quick wins.

Shall we start?
scripts.role:
Great. Let's start with the basics.

What is your role in the company?

Nice to meet you, {role}. Perspective matters.

What industry do you operate in?
scripts.industrySub: Production. Got it. What kind specifically?
scripts.size: How many employees do you have roughly?
scripts.country:
Understood. Scale changes the available solutions.

Which country is your main operation in?
scripts.challenges:
Great, let's explore your current challenges to build meaningful recommendations.

What is your main operational pain point (Select one or type)

7A.title: Data & AI Foundations
7A.level1Desc: Data are scattered across spreadsheets, local drives and disconnected systems. There is no unified view of the organization's information. Data is incomplete or inconsistent across systems. AI cannot function because data is not available in the right format.
level1Questions: Do you have trouble accessing data?
Is data locked in separate systems?
7A.level2Desc: The company has several digital systems (ERP, MES, CRM), but each stores data in its own 'silo'. Data is more structured but not easily accessible to AI. Exports are done manually. Data is digital but unconnected.
level2Questions: Do you have a central data warehouse?
Does preparing data require manual work?
7A.level3Desc: The organization builds the first centralized data repositories. ETL processes start functioning. First machine learning projects appear, based on standardized datasets. Data in the warehouse is updated regularly.
level3Questions: Do data scientists have easy access to raw data?
Do you monitor key data quality?
7A.level4Desc: The organization has consistent governance rules, data quality is monitored, and sources are documented. Data is available in near real-time. AI models have stable, scalable pipelines.
level4Questions: Does every dataset have an owner?
Are there SLAs for data availability?
7A.level5Desc: Data is automatically prepared, cleaned, versioned, and shared with AI models. Systems can detect anomalies, fill gaps, and optimize data flows without human intervention. Data is treated as a product.
level5Questions: Can business users use data independently?

7B.title: AI-Augmented Processes
7B.level1Desc: AI appears only as small, unrelated initiatives (tests, chatbots, OCR). They have no impact on main business processes. AI works 'next to' processes, not inside them.
level1Questions: Is AI just a curiosity in the company?
Are AI tests done without a plan?
Is there no impact on main processes?
7B.level2Desc: AI supports employees but does not decide. First automations appear (scheduling, content generation). AI's role is to speed up human work. AI improves efficiency but doesn't affect process quality.
level2Questions: Does AI automate simple office tasks?
Do employees use AI as an assistant?
Does AI speed up work but not change it?
7B.level3Desc: AI becomes part of the process. Models provide operational recommendations. Employees make decisions based on AI. Processes utilize data and algorithms, but responsibility remains with humans.
level3Questions: Does AI suggest decisions to employees?
Do processes consider AI model results?
7B.level4Desc: AI performs part of process activities independently. Humans supervise or approve. In many processes, humans no longer make decisions — only control the system.
level4Questions: Does the system make routine decisions alone?
Is the human role just approving?
7B.level5Desc: Processes are designed to be executed by autonomous AI systems. AI monitors, reacts, and optimizes. Humans handle supervision and strategy. Processes execute entirely without human participation.
level5Questions: Do processes run without human interference?
Does AI optimize its own operation?

7C.title: AI in Products & Services

levels.3: AI as a Core Product Component

7C.level1Desc: Products and services contain no AI elements. Value comes from traditional functions. Products work the same for every user. No predictive functions.
level1Questions: Does every client get the same thing?
7C.level2Desc: AI appears as an additional module enhancing the product. AI functions are enhancements (recommendations). AI improves UX but the product still has a classic structure.
level2Questions: Is AI just an add-on (e.g. recommendations)?
Would the product work without this add-on?
Does AI improve UX but not change features?
7C.level3Desc: AI becomes a key element of product architecture. The product 'understands' the user, adapts, and reacts to data. The product differs from competitors thanks to AI.
level3Questions: Is AI key to product operation?
Does the product adapt to the user?
Would the product lose sense without AI?
7C.level4Desc: AI is responsible for most product logic and dynamically adjusts operation. Functionality is personalized, adaptive, and self-improving.
level4Questions: Does the product learn on the fly?
7C.level5Desc: Products couldn't exist without AI. AI creates the entire business model. Autonomous systems, agents, digital twins. The product is an intelligent system.
level5Questions: Is the business model based on AI?
Is this a completely new product category?
Is the product an autonomous agent?

7D.title: Governance, Security & Ethics
7D.level1Desc: AI is used spontaneously and without supervision. No usage policies or security rules. The organization is unaware of risks.
level1Questions: Do employees use private AI accounts for work?
Is there no data protection policy for AI?
Is the firm unaware of AI legal risks?
7D.level2Desc: The organization creates basic AI usage rules (do's & don'ts). Policies are informational and not yet fully enforced.
level2Questions: Are there written 'Do's & Don'ts' for AI?
Was training on safe AI use conducted?
Does legal verify ad-hoc AI tools?
7D.level3Desc: The firm formalizes its AI approach. Project acceptance processes, risk assessment criteria, dedicated roles. Models are versioned and audited.
level3Questions: Does every AI deployment undergo risk assessment?
7D.level4Desc: The organization has a continuous structured control system. Real-time model monitoring, drift detection. AI treated as critical infrastructure.
level4Questions: Are AI models classified by risk level?
Are there standards for documenting AI decisions?
7D.level5Desc: AI governance is automated and built-in. Systems detect problems and react. The firm proves transparency to auditors.
level5Questions: Are systems transparent to the end user?
Do clients trust how the firm uses their data?

7E.title: Competence & AI Culture
7E.level1Desc: Employees lack AI skills. Skepticism or fear dominates. Knowledge is limited to media reports.
level1Questions: Are there no people who understand AI?
Do employees fear AI will replace them?
does HR not recruit data specialists?
7E.level2Desc: Some use simple tools on their own. No systemic training. Competence acquired mainly externally.
level2Questions: Do you rely 100% on external providers?
Does knowledge disappear after the project?
Are there no business 'translators' for AI?
7E.level3Desc: Firm provides training and tools. Defined roles. First team successes. Internal AI team formed.
level3Questions: Do you have an internal AI team or leaders?
Does this team collaborate with business?
7E.level4Desc: Employees build simple automations (Citizen Developers). Continuous upskilling is norm. Culture of experimentation.
level4Questions: Do employees create AI/Low-code solutions themselves?
Does everyone have access to AI tools?
7E.level5Desc: Human-AI collaboration is seamless. Employees manage AI agents. Organization attracts top talents.
level5Questions: Does every employee have a 'digital assistant'?
Does work without AI feel unnatural?
Do you attract AI talent from the market?
